unnormalised: Someone asked me the other day, "Yaar, how much material will I need for my new house?" It's a common question, especially when you're building from scratch. See, it's not just about saying you need 100 bags of cement. You've gotta think about dimensions.
normalised: Someone asked me the other day, "Yaar, how much material will I need for my new house?" It's a common question, especially when you're building from scratch. See, it's not just about saying you need one hundred bags of cement. You've gotta think about dimensions.

unnormalised: First, get your measurements right! You'll need to know the length, breadth, and height of all the walls in metres. Don't guesstimate! Precise numbers are key here. For example, if a wall is 4.5 m long and 3 m high, that's your starting point. Plus, what thickness are you going for? Is it a standard 9 inch wall or something thinner?
normalised: First, get your measurements right! You'll need to know the length, breadth, and height of all the walls in meters. Don't guesstimate! Precise numbers are key here. For example, if a wall is four point five meters long and three meters high, that's your starting point. Plus, what thickness are you going for? Is it a standard nine inch wall or something thinner?

unnormalised: Next, calculate the volume of concrete you'll need, probably measured in cubic meters (m3). For steel, you'll need the length and diameter of the rods, often sold by the kg or even by the tonne. Sand and aggregate are usually quoted in cu. ft or even truckloads. Get quotes from 2-3 suppliers so you are not cheated. Remember those guys might quote at Rs. 2500/cu. ft but you might get a better deal elsewhere.
normalised: Next, calculate the volume of concrete you'll need, probably measured in cubic meters (m3). For steel, you'll need the length and diameter of the rods, often sold by the kilogram or even by the tonne. Sand and aggregate are usually quoted in cubic feet or even truckloads. Get quotes from two to three suppliers so you are not cheated. Remember those guys might quote at rupee two thousand five hundred per cubic foot but you might get a better deal elsewhere.

unnormalised: Then, factor in wastage! Always add a bit extra. A general rule of thumb is to add 5% to 10% for wastage depending on the complexity of the design. So, if you calculated 1000 kgs of steel, order 1050 to 1100 kgs just to be safe. Nobody likes running short mid-construction.
normalised: Then, factor in wastage! Always add a bit extra. A general rule of thumb is to add five percent to ten percent for wastage depending on the complexity of the design. So, if you calculated one thousand kilograms of steel, order one thousand and fifty to one thousand one hundred kilograms just to be safe. Nobody likes running short mid-construction.

unnormalised: Finally, best advice I can give you is: hire a good architect or contractor. They will calculate all of this for you accurately and save you a lot of headache. Trying to DIY this can be a real mess. Trust me.
normalised: Finally, best advice I can give you is: hire a good architect or contractor. They will calculate all of this for you accurately and save you a lot of headache. Trying to D-I-Y this can be a real mess. Trust me.
